Topic: Draw a habitat and the different living things in each
CAN: The student can identify and draw a basic land habitat like a garden or playground, with some elements such as grass and a few trees.
The student can include a small number of living things such as one or two animals (e.g., a squirrel and an ant) in the habitat.
The student can draw a simple water habitat, like a pond, and add a couple of elements such as water and a fish.
CANNOT: The student is likely unable to consistently show a variety of different land and water habitats in detail (student may only focus on one type of habitat).
The student struggles to accurately represent and label a wide range of living things in their drawing (many living things are not included or are inaccurately depicted).
The student may have difficulty showing and labeling plant diversity, often including just one type or mislabeling plants (e.g., calling grass a tree).

The student is unable to effectively depict clear patterns or comparisons between habitats in terms of plant and animal diversity (student may use the same few elements across different habitats without variation).
